form.steps:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a slight bend in your knees. Hold a barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 
2. Hinge at your hips and lean forward, maintaining a straight back and a neutral spine. Let the barbell hang down from your shoulders with your arms fully extended. This is your starting position. 
3. Inhale and pull the barbell up towards your chest, keeping your elbows high and wide, pointing out to the sides. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 
4. Hold for a brief pause at the top, ensuring your rear deltoids are fully contracted. 
5. With control, lower the barbell back to the starting position, straightening your arms.

form.Grip: Overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width.
form.Back: Keep your back straight, maintaining a neutral spine throughout the exercise. Avoid rounding your back.
form.Elbows: Keep your elbows high and wide, pointing out to the sides as you pull the barbell.
form.Shoulders: Pull your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement to fully engage the rear deltoids.
form.Torso: Maintain a consistent angle of your torso throughout the exercise. Avoid using momentum or swinging your body.

commonMistakes.Using Too Much Weight: Using excessive weight can lead to improper form and reduce the effectiveness of the exercise. It can also put unnecessary stress on your shoulders and lower back.
commonMistakes.Rounding the Back: Rounding your back during the exercise can lead to lower back pain and injury. Maintain a straight back throughout the movement.
commonMistakes.Not Pulling Elbows High Enough: Not raising your elbows high enough will shift the focus away from the rear deltoids and onto the traps and rhomboids.
commonMistakes.Using Momentum: Swinging the weight up using momentum will reduce the effectiveness of the exercise. Focus on using a controlled movement and squeezing your rear deltoids at the top.

comments.Target Muscles: The barbell rear delt row is a compound exercise that primarily targets the rear deltoids and upper back muscles, including the trapezius and rhomboids. It also engages the biceps and forearms to a lesser extent.
comments.Importance of Rear Delt Training: Developing strong rear deltoids is crucial for overall shoulder health, posture, and injury prevention. It also contributes to a balanced physique and improves performance in other exercises like overhead presses and rows.
comments.Variations: The barbell rear delt row can be varied by using different grip widths and hand positions. A closer grip will emphasize the rear deltoids, while a wider grip will engage more of the traps. You can also use dumbbells or a cable machine for variations.
comments.Progression: As you get stronger, you can increase the weight, reps, or sets to continue challenging your muscles. You can also try more advanced variations like the Pendlay row or the T-bar row.

alternativesAndVariations.Dumbbell Rear Delt Row: This variation allows for a greater range of motion and independent arm movement, which can help address muscle imbalances.
alternativesAndVariations.Face Pulls: This exercise is excellent for targeting the rear deltoids and improving shoulder stability. It can be performed with a rope attachment on a cable machine.
alternativesAndVariations.Reverse Flyes: This exercise can be done with dumbbells or a cable machine and is effective for isolating the rear deltoids.
alternativesAndVariations.Bent-Over Dumbbell Rows: While primarily a back exercise, bent-over dumbbell rows also engage the rear deltoids as secondary movers.

barbell-rear-delt-row.tempo: 2011 (2 seconds pulling, 0 seconds pause at the top, 1 second lowering, 1 second pause at the bottom)
